  6. Could not find one of these in the store, so finally found on Amazon. Have had these in the past and when we remodeled the master bath in the old house, didn't need it any more. But we moved and this is a better solution that remodeling the bathroom! Works great and well packaged. Much superior than the round, lighted mirrors at Target, Walmart, etc. Would recommend.
  7. Still decided to take a chance on buying this after reading a lot of negativity in people's reviews. I turned it on for 3-5 minutes each morning for maybe 3 mornings before it broke - lights stayed off, burnt hair smell coming out of it, etc. Got a prompt exchange from Amazon (which arrived the first couple days of August) and I haven't had trouble with it yet, so that's almost 3 months now, yay! It's not perfect, but good enough for the money. The slider to select which type of lighting you want is a little crooked and you can still see the edges of the other colors that you don't have selected. Sometimes I wish I could stand it up a little straighter, but it isn't a major problem. Good for the money if you can get a working one!<br /><br />UPDATE:<br />OMG, the day after I posted this review I turned it on and the lights made a noise and went out! Less than 3 months and it's broken again :( Totally never buying this product again.

They didn't even ask me to return the broken mirror - told me to just cut the cord and trash it. I am pretty happy w/ their customer service.

  46. This is a nice mirror, but it is actually a bit larger than I expected. It has an adjustable back so that it can be set to sit at different reclining angles, sort of like a lawn chair. The lighting is adjustable, too, but it not quite as bright as I had hoped. It's not bad, though. The middle mirror is also adjustable within it's frame. One side is a regular mirror, and on the flip side is the magnifying mirror. I just with that the outlet cord were a bit longer -- it's about 5 feet long. I've been satisfied so far with the mirror for the price I paid.<br /><br />Warning: I have actually had to purchase 2 of these. The first one started to burn when I had the lights on for a prolonged period of time. It smelled like it would catch on fire, so I got rid of it, got another, and now I am careful not to leave the lights on for more than 20 minutes at a time. It's been fine.
  47. I was setting up the mirror to put on my makeup and the piece that holds the stand up broke off into pieces so now I have to prop the mirror up in order to see into it. I think the material is very cheap. This should not have happened. Now I have to go and research another mirror other than this one!
  48. When my Clairol True Light Mirror (that I bought in the late 1970's) finally broke in 2010, I bought this mirror because it looked a lot like the Clairol one. I was not disappointed at first. The light was bright and the 5 mag mirror was perfect - not wavy at all. But after 4 years both lights burned out and they cannot be replaced. There are 4 slits on the back of my mirror, and no tool fits in them. So I ordered a second Jerdon mirror. It arrived quickly. The light is bright, but the 5 mag mirror is so wavy it hurts my eyes to look at it. And that is the side of the mirror I have been using lately. I tried to get used to it, but it really hurts my eyes. It also has the 4 slits in the back, so the bulbs cannot be changed either. So I am returning it. I love the lighting on this mirror, but the 5 mag is fun house worthy!
  49. I read all the product reviews before I purchased this mirror but couldn't believe the negative comments about the lighting could be as bad as some said. Several said it was fine. After trying to use mine, I agree that the lighting is horrible. I am not impressed with the lack of light and still be listed as \\"LIGHTED\\". The bulbs create such a small amount of light, regardless of the setting used, that I just don't use the light at all. Very disappointed. Would rather have light!
  50. My mother had a make-up mirror that was a Remington and it broke after many years of use, so I purchased this Jerdon lighted mirror and she loves it just like the old Remington. That is why I give it 5 stars for the product and the service from Amazon free shipping and fast service too!
  51. It looked new or refurbished. Mount/Stand is flimsy plastic and could break easily so you have to treat this thing like a newborn. I guess they made it that way so you can keep buying more of these products. Could be built more sturdy. But everything works fine. 4 stars.
  52. This lighted mirror is ok. The lighting is kind of dull and could be better. What I really like best about the lighted mirror is the electrical plug on the front, which is great for plugging in a hair dryer or curling iron.

  64. I used to have an 8x magnification round make up mirror, but because it was smaller and round it gave a pretty distorted image, and I couldn't see enough of my face at one time. I decided to give this one a try even though it is only 5x magnification. I tried this one because the mirror is larger and rectangular so I can see my entire face, and it is far less distorted than the round ones.<br /><br />You can select lighting based on time of day and / or location by using a simple slide bar. It also has two side mirrors that you can extend outward to see yourself in profile on the left or profile on the right. Or simply extend the mirrors for a wider view (in 1x magnification only).<br /><br />I would definitely buy this one again, and I will recommend it to all my friends!

  66. Got it yesterday, it is back in its box today ready for return. I seriously thought I was going to have a seizure when testing the magnification mirror.   68. To start let me say that I am a fifteen year old girl, but don't let that discourage you from reading my review. I know an awful lot about makeup and I have been using makeup for three years. I am very talented and I know a good makeup-related item when I use it. I had this mirror for a year (I got it as a Christmas gift) and I am here to share my honest opinion of this mirror.<br /><br />Other important details I must discuss before I share my thoughts: I used this mirror early in the morning, and kept it in my room.<br /><br />This mirror is very useful. I got it as a Christmas gift and I was simply thrilled. As time passed I did find some features which were not up to my standards. First, I found that all the different settings for lighting (for me) were unnecessary, I only used the first setting, it suited the time which I would be wearing my makeup the best. I also found that my mirror liked to fall down from time to time, which I found annoying.<br /><br />The most upsetting feature I found was that the mirror was not very attractive. I had it displayed in my room and it looked very, let's say \\"hospital-like\\", cold and, in a way, unwelcoming. I put stickers on it to make it look more attractive but it still had that harsh feeling.<br /><br />I also found that the light was too bright for someone who just woke up. The light can hurt your eyes, so be cautious when using it.<br /><br />However, I did find the mirror very useful for makeup, I could see every nook and cranny of my face and make myself look as attractive as possible.<br /><br />Eventually the light bulbs inside the mirror died, and I did not know how to change them. As time passed I found the now less-useful mirror to be even more unattractive, and I threw it away.<br /><br />Now I use an ordinary wall mirror and I direct a normal desk light at my face. It works just as well and it is far more attractive than that bulky ugly mirror. The only thing I am missing out on is the 5x magnification, but sometimes you're better off not getting a more detailed look at your face.<br /><br />Although the mirror is useful, you're probably better off just using your bathroom mirror or a mirror and light in your room, far more attractive and with around the same amount of function.etimes you're better off not getting a more detailed look at your face.<br /><br />Although the mirror is useful, you're probably better off just using your bathroom mirror or a mirror and light in your room, far more attractive and with around the same amount of function.

  101. I've had this mirror for perhaps ten days now and, although it is a bit bigger and dimmer than I had imagined, it appears to be a good product for a reasonable price. My dressing table has maddeningly low lighting directed at the ceiling (which doesn't help much), so this purchase was intended to correct the situation. It's slide mechanism for changing to different lighting situations (day, evening, office, and home) when one may presumably be seen in daylight (less makeup?), low light (more makeup?), beneath fluorescent light (aging), and around incandescent light (more flattering), respectively, and thereby be applying makeup differently, strikes me as rather misguided. Many of us are using fluorescent lighting throughout our homes these day, and, with the exception of the Day setting, the three other settings aren't bright enough to be all that functional (for my aging eyes). Nonetheless, the Day setting is fine, and it's helpful to have the two side mirrors, along with a choice to flip to a magnified mirror when needed.<br /><br />I noticed that some purchasers had an on-off button which they had to hold down for a few seconds in order to get the lights to turn on and stay on... mine has a toggle switch which turns the lights on immediately, so I can't comment on their issue with this. Perhaps Jergon has changed the feature now? Also, a few people noted that one of their doors would not stay in place. There, again, mine are tightly hinged and stay where I set them.<br /><br />All inexpensive products (and especially those made of plastic) need to be handled gently, and will last surprisingly long with a little care. All in all, it was a good purchase for the price.

My last one became very difficult to move and it eventually broke off every time I tried to move it.<br /><br />All in all, the option to change the lighting is fantastic and it gives off plenty of light to be able to do my makeup in low light situations. If the light begins to act up I will update my review. I also really like how it folds up. It is rather large but I was still able to fit it in a carry on bag and travel with it; it also survived in my checked luggage on the way back. The ONLY reason it doesn't get 5 stars is because I wish it was a little sleeker looking. This mirror looks straight out of the 80s, so you probably wouldn't want to leave it out on your vanity for guests to see.
  152. This product came and was true to its description. It is a tri-fold mirror with very bright lights. I purchased it for my 15 year old daughter. The bright lights triggered an ocular migraine and then triggered the first migraine headache that she had ever had. I would recommend it to the not so light sensitive.

  154. I read the reviews here and went out and bought one anyway, because it truly is brighter than the majority of lit mirrors available. I've loved it for the past 4 months, but recently in the past couple of weeks it has developed the lag time. The bulb still works, but like others have experienced, there is now about a 5 second lapse between the time that I flip the switch and the time that the light comes on. This started out a couple weeks ago as 2 seconds, then gradually increased, and I can only imagine that it will continue to do so. :( I have not had any problems with the bulb burning out as of yet. The problem is annoying but manageable....however if it were to become 15 or 30 seconds I'd probably become really frustrated. Otherwise, I think the mirror would be the best one available. I switch between \\"daylight\\" and \\"home\\" because I find that \\"office\\" is simply green and \\"evening\\" doesn't provide enough light. Also, the stand is a little flimsy and can easily be toppled over, so they should build in some kind of lock to keep it more secure. The outlet in the base of the mirror is very convenient, though I wouldn't risk it with higher voltage appliances.<br /><br />EDIT: About a month after writing the review above, I turned on my mirror and it no longer comes on. Yes, I tried holding the ON button for a while. Nothing. It's dead.
  155. Old tri-fold makeup mirror needed to be replaced. Purchased the Jerdon JGL9W as it was very similar. Side mirror panels open up easily, clear, unmarred reflection.   162. I received the Jerdon JGL9W mirror as a gift and within 6 months, the bulbs burned out. Holding down the on button does not work for me, as mine is a simple \\"on\\" or \\"off\\" switch, and not a button that I can hold down. The bulbs don't flicker at all, no matter how many times I try to leave it on or turn it off and back on again.<br /><br />Finally, after reading all the Amazon reviews, I contacted Jerdon and spoke with their customer service at 800-223-3571. Apparently, since this is a known, ongoing issue, the company is replacing the mirrors free of charge, no receipt required. Instead, they ask that you cut off the plug from your cord and mail it to the following address, along with the model # and your return address: Jerdon - Customer Service Department, 1820 N. Glenville Drive, Suite 124, Richardson, TX 75081. I asked why, and was told that they Jerdon ships the plugs to their manufacturer for credit.<br /><br />The mirror that they send will be the same model, so I would imagine that I'll likely encounter the same problem again at some point. However, since it's free and they replace it without a receipt, I figure that it can't hurt. I love every other aspect of this product EXCEPT the terrible life of the bulbs, so it's worth the bit of hassle until I find a better mirror or Jerdon creates a better model. My review would be a 5 star but for the life of the bulbs.

  178. I just received my Jerdon JGL9W 5X Magnification Tri-Fold Lighted Mirror. Ordinarily, I would wait to review a product until I'd used it for a while but, since I bought this based on the good reviews I read here, I decided to warn people about its shortcomings as soon as possible.<br /><br />Besides, it doesn't take that long to see the problems here.<br /><br />It's the low quality of the magnifying mirror that is the biggest problem (but not the only one). And the magnifying mirror is the main reason to purchase this product, IMHO.<br /><br />I received the mirror in a very timely manner and in good condition. The packaging was more than adequate. I plugged it in and it turned on.<br /><br />What don't I like? Where do I start?<br /><br />Well, worst of all, the 5X magnifying mirror is concave and, therefore, warps the image.<br /><br />Besides that, the mirrors in general are low quality, the side mirror doors will not close completely unless you have the non-magnifying side on the front, and it's front heavy. The lighting is also nothing to get excited about.<br /><br />Regarding the front heavy part, my vanity stool is fairly low so I wanted to have it pretty upright. But at the highest of the settings that are grouped together it wants to tilt over onto me.<br /><br />Yes, I can tilt the middle mirror so I can get by with a more slanted setting, but not the side mirrors.<br /><br />The worst problem: The 5X mirror, which is very low quality to begin with, is concave. This is apparently deliberate because the plastic housing for that side of the mirror is also concave. It's been designed that way, though I have no idea why.<br /><br />Is there some reason I'm not aware of why a 5X mirror has to be concave?<br /><br />The other mirrors are not terrible; nothing to brag about but not that bad. But I buy a makeup mirror for the magnification, and the magnifying mirror on this product is terrible.<br /><br />Put together the low quality of the mirror AND the warp from the concave shape and I can only see myself somewhat clearly (in small areas, not my whole face at once) if I lean way forward and am within about 5-6 inches of the mirror. Even then, it's not a good image at all, and I'm uncomfortable to boot.<br /><br />And the lights... well, I did not have to hold a button down to get it to turn on as I've read is the case. This is a simple toggle switch and the lights come on instantly. But the quality of the lighting is not good, either. Can this really be the same model where I've read people brag about the lighting?<br /><br />I think the only setting I could use would be the Day setting. The Office setting makes everything look green, and the other settings don't light up what I'm trying to see well enough.<br /><br />I had an oval Conair that I did not consider to be very good and, when it finally died, I chose this one because it sounded like a much higher quality product.<br /><br />The Conair, with all its shortcomings, is much to be preferred over this product.<br /><br />One could learn to live with the problems with the casing, the less than wonderful flat mirrors, etc. Even the lighting, since there is one setting that would work reasonably well for me.<br /><br />But the problems with the magnifying mirror are, as best I can tell, insurmountable. Much as I dislike the hassle of returning something, this will have to go back. Unless, of course, someone out there knows some magic where this situation is concerned.not my whole face at once) if I lean way forward and am within about 5-6 inches of the mirror. Even then, it's not a good image at all, and I'm uncomfortable to boot. And the lights... well, I did not have to hold a button down to get it to turn on as I've read is the case. This is a simple toggle switch and the lights come on instantly. But the quality of the lighting is not good, either. Can this really be the same model where I've read people brag about the lighting? I think the only setting I could use would be the Day setting. The Office setting makes everything look green, and the other settings don't light up what I'm trying to see well enough. I had an oval Conair that I did not consider to be very good and, when it finally died, I chose this one because it sounded like a much higher quality product. The Conair, with all its shortcomings, is much to be preferred over this product. One could learn to live with the problems with the casing, the less than wonderful flat mirrors, etc. Even the lighting, since there is one setting that would work reasonably well for me. But the problems with the magnifying mirror are, as best I can tell, insurmountable. Much as I dislike the hassle of returning something, this will have to go back. Unless, of course, someone out there knows some magic where this situation is concerned.

I went ahead and ordered the mirror and to my great surprise it was everything I had hoped it was. I have absolutely NO issues with this product, the lights turn on when I push the button and the outlet on the mirror itself works wonderful.   186. How do you take the Jerdon Model JGL9W apart?<br /><br />DO NOT TRY TO PRY IT APART! That will NEVER work. I tried that. That is some tough plastic. I found out that the back is not made to simply pop off. And no amount of prying will get it off. The unit is held together by four (4) rather substantial screws.<br /><br />Where are the screws? On the back of the unit you will see four (4) round slightly recessed areas. The recessed plastic inside of these four circles hides the screw heads. If you take a medium size phillips screw driver and press it into the center of that circle you should penetrate through the 1/16 inch or so of the covering plastic, and find the screw head right underneath.<br /><br />(I used the word \\"if\\" and \\"should\\" because I removed the plastic with a 5/16 inch forstner bit on my drill press, not knowing what was under there. I thought it was a support post, internally glued, and I was going to separate it from the back by removing the plastic material around it. But, to my surprise, the drill bit hit metal quickly, and in that way I found the screw head.)<br /><br />Note: Before you seperate the front and the back of the unit, use the flat end of a screw driver to pop out the slider knob.<br /><br />With that caveat, when you get those four screws out, the unit comes apart easily.<br /><br />Why did I take it apart? This unit worked fine for one year, and 11 months, wherein, it came to pass, that both of the lights stopped working. Even if you held the switch down for a minute the lights would not light.<br /><br />Now, because both lights would not light, I figured it was probably not an issue with the lights themselves. I thought I might find something wrong with the switch. When I had the unit apart, and I plugged it in, I operated the switch, and it had a different feel to it, it clicked on, and it clicked off. Before I took the unit apart, the switch had no such mechanical feedback. I am not sure what I did to invoke that change in behavior. Nevertheless, I was rewarded for my efforts, as is often the case in situations like this, where you make the effort, but you are not sure exactly what you did to make it work, but by golly, both the lights come on now!<br /><br />And so, if I had not broken one of the small brackets that holds one end of one of the lense movement assemblies during my effort to pry the unit apart with a big screwdriver, I could simply put it back together and give it back to my mom, as the lights appears to work fine now. But because of this broken bracket issue I need to figure out how to glue it back on before I can put it back together. I don't see a major problem there. (Update: that was no problem. I made a new bracket, glued it on, and the unit is reassembled and functioning properly).<br /><br />While looking inside this unit, I must report to you, that it is well made, and quite substantial. I think people who buy this unit are getting a good deal. All electrical connections are made with solid crimp connections, and everything is well insulated. The ballast transformer looks to be so substantial that one might expect it to last for a century or more. And the lense movement assemblies are quite cleverly and substantially designed too.<br /><br />For those of you who want to know how to change the fluorescent light bulbs in this unit, i.e. if they ever did fail, well then, you would take the unit apart as described above. Beyond that, the rest is speculation on my part derived from looking at the issue from the inside. As noted I did not need to replace the bulbs in this unit.<br /><br />Inside the case, on a label close to the bulbs, it tells you what kind of bulb you need. However, the bulbs do not have sockets. They are hard wired in there with crimp connectors. To remove the old bulb or bulbs, you would have to clip the wires close to the bulb pins, remove the old bulbs, and put in the new ones, and then crimp the wires back onto the pins ofthe new bulb. I suppose you could solder the wires on, using some shrink wrap insulation to make sure that there is no bare metal showing after you are done.<br /><br />For a person to accomplish this successfully, you would need to have some electrical knowledge before hand. Not a lot, but some. Like don't work on the unit while it's plugged in. And how to crimp, or solder, and how to insulate the bulb pin connections. And how to keep track of where the wires go. You could take a digital photo first, before you disconnect anything.<br /><br />Moreover, the replacement of the light bulbs would be further complicated by the fact that these light bulbs are mounted inside of the lens movement mechanisms. It appears that the main mounting bracket (one per side) for the lens movement mechanism must be unscrewed and moved at least partially out of the way before you can get your hands on the phenolic strips which serve as the mounting structure for the bulbs, and through which the pins extend. I poked around in there and tried to see how these might come out. It is not clear. It Looks like somewhat of a mechanical puzzle. And when it comes to the lens movement mechanism, we are speaking about a string driven spring loaded apparatus, and it will take some mechanical aptitude to get it put back together and properly realigned, that is tracking from side to side.<br /><br />(To adjust tracking, you need to relieve the string tension on one side, and spin the lens into the proper position. I needed to do this before I put this unit back together.)<br /><br />Replacing the light bulbs in this unit is not impossible. But it would NOT be considered easy. Apart from the time it would take to find the right replacement bulbs, and have them at hand ready to install, I think you would be talking about a couple of hours of shop time, factoring in the time you will need to explore and fathom just how to get the old bulbs out of there.<br /><br />A factory technician who has done this a hundred times, who has the bulbs, the tools, and the experience, might be able to complete the job in about fifteen minutes. A person who sees the inside of this unit for the first time will take longer.<br /><br />If you are electrically and mechanically inclined, and have the time to spare, it might be an enjoyable project, which would pay some dividends, I think, in terms of making the end-user very happy. Giving new life to an old friend will certainly give her something to smile about.wrap insulation to make sure that there is no bare metal showing after you are done. For a person to accomplish this successfully, you would need to have some electrical knowledge before hand. Not a lot, but some. Like don't work on the unit while it's plugged in. And how to crimp, or solder, and how to insulate the bulb pin connections. And how to keep track of where the wires go. You could take a digital photo first, before you disconnect anything. Moreover, the replacement of the light bulbs would be further complicated by the fact that these light bulbs are mounted inside of the lens movement mechanisms. It appears that the main mounting bracket (one per side) for the lens movement mechanism must be unscrewed and moved at least partially out of the way before you can get your hands on the phenolic strips which serve as the mounting structure for the bulbs, and through which the pins extend. I poked around in there and tried to see how these might come out. It is not clear. It Looks like somewhat of a mechanical puzzle. And when it comes to the lens movement mechanism, we are speaking about a string driven spring loaded apparatus, and it will take some mechanical aptitude to get it put back together and properly realigned, that is tracking from side to side. (To adjust tracking, you need to relieve the string tension on one side, and spin the lens into the proper position. I needed to do this before I put this unit back together.) Replacing the light bulbs in this unit is not impossible. But it would NOT be considered easy. Apart from the time it would take to find the right replacement bulbs, and have them at hand ready to install, I think you would be talking about a couple of hours of shop time, factoring in the time you will need to explore and fathom just how to get the old bulbs out of there. A factory technician who has done this a hundred times, who has the bulbs, the tools, and the experience, might be able to complete the job in about fifteen minutes. A person who sees the inside of this unit for the first time will take longer. If you are electrically and mechanically inclined, and have the time to spare, it might be an enjoyable project, which would pay some dividends, I think, in terms of making the end-user very happy. Giving new life to an old friend will certainly give her something to smile about.
  187. I started using this type of mirror in the 1970's. It was a revlon brand I believe. Jerdon is the only mirror I have been able to find that is still made like these were.   197. I had no expectations when I purchased it, so I thinks it's fair to say it's OK.   211. After 20+ years, my Jerdon makeup mirror finally died. As many others have noted, along with myself, it is hard to find a really good makeup mirror with the right amount of brightness. It seems the the new round kind do not put off enough light to see yourself. Well, when I found this Jerdon mirror on Amazon, I was very excited. I read all the reviews and knew what folks where saying when they referenced the on/off switch and that you had to hold down for 10 seconds for the lights to stay on. Since this makeup mirror served me well over the past 20+ years, I didn't care and purchased another one. To my very pleasant surprise, the makeup mirror was identical to my previous mirror, but they improved the on/off switch. It is more a hard on/off flip vs. the soft hold for 10 seconds. Maybe I needed to clean my previous mirror more, but the magnification side almost scared me -- wow, found hairs on my face I didn't know I had :)<br />Would highly recommend this mirror if you are looking for a good mirror to replace your mirror from years ago, or younger girls just starting out with makeup.

  232. Here's why.... I searched high and low for a decent lighted makeup mirror similiar to the one I had for years. My old mirror was a Windmere, lasted about 12 years. Prior to that I had a Clairol (lighting was just OK). Days of web searches led me to those horrible round halo lighted mirrors (they just look good on a counter) and serve no purpose. This Jerdon is basically the same mirror as my old Windmere. Very sturdy, great lighting, large rectangle mirror, side mirrors, vertical 360' rotation, 5X magnification on reverse side of mirror and 11 mirror positions, also an extra electrical outlet on front for appliances. The ISSUE regarding previous reviewers complaints about the lighting. You MUST hold the ON button down about 3 seconds to allow for the bulbs to light. The lighting on this mirror is superior to others I have seen. It weighs about 6 lbs and folds nicely away. The negatives to this mirror are: the bulbs make a slight buzzing noise when in use (typical of this type of bulb) and the electrical outlet was installed upside down on my product, therefore the mirror must be collapsed to a lower position to allow enough room for the plug. I consider these to be minor complaints considering the product services all my needs. If you want to go out of the house looking like you intend, this is the mirror for you. I would definitely buy again.

  244. This mirror is very similar to the Windmere unit that I had for about 10 years and loved until it wouldn't turn on any more. The lighting on the Jerdon is clean and bright and the overall design is good. However, the quality of the mirrors is such that the reflection is distorted, especially on the magnified side. I'm not talking about the distortion that the magnification naturally creates. Unlike the magnification distortion, my eyes take a few moments to adjust to this distortion (sort of like putting on someone else's prescription eyeglasses). This is likely due to the reflective surface being of a lesser optical quality. So far it's the the best I've found without spending big bucks, but perhaps that's why some other mirrors are more expensive.<br /><br />7/3/10 UPDATE. I have found the distortion the mirror causes to be too irritating. Also, the lights are taking longer and longer to turn on. I will be looking for a different mirror soon.

  282. I purchased this makeup mirror over 16 months ago, and it still works as wonderfully as it did the day I bought it. I use this at least once daily for about10- 20 minutes. I love having the four different light settings, and will often do a quick \\"check\\" how my makeup looks after I'm finished applying it under all 4 light conditions. I primarily use the center mirror flipped over to the magnified side with the daylight setting for tweezing my eyebrows and for applying mascara, occasionally liquid eyeliner. For me, the daylight setting is the brightest and helps me to see every detail, and with my astigmatism, this has helped me a great deal. FYI, the side mirrors are adjustable from side to side, but are not magnified, in case that is important to you.<br /><br />I love the extra outlet, and will most often use it to plug in my vacuum cleaner of all things, when I vacuum our bedroom, rather than a curling iron or hair dryer, like most normal people would, as I prefer doing my hair in the bathroom. The easle portion of the back of this makeup mirror makes it easily adjustable to however I need it, so I'm not stuck having to sit in one or two particular positions to use this. Also, the two side mirrors help me to see the side views of my face while applying my blush, so I can be sure it looks right from not only head-on with the main mirror, but also from the sides WHILE applying.<br /><br />This makeup mirror and it's exterior are very easily cleaned and shutting the side mirror doors when finished helps keep the interior mirrored portions dust-free. The back easel stand is collapsible if you so choose, and this makes it easy to store if you don't want to leave it sitting out.<br /><br />For me, this has been a wonderful and versatile makeup mirror that has allowed me to see very clearly what I'm doing.

  287. I bought two of these for my daughters back in January. They haven't used them very much, but one of them has the lights burned out already. I guess I should have paid more attention to the bad reviews. If you get unlucky and get a bad unit, then you're stuck with it if it's after 30 days from the purchase. I can't find any way to contact someone about the supposed one year warranty. I am surprised that Amazon doesn't offer any help since this is an item that they are selling directly. Oh well, I guess that's my good money down the drain. Everyone beware and don't buy this!<br /><br />Update 10/2/10 I found the customer inquiry number for jerdon and spoke with them about the mirror. They had me return the cord of the unit and then shipped me a new one. It took about a month to get here, but it arrived last week. So I can vouch for the fact the company does stand by its warranty. I have changed my rating from a one to a three, since I still believe that the quality of the units are lacking since so many people are complaining about the units going out in such a short time. My original unit did not last long, and, as of right now, I have no faith that the new one will last any longer than the first one. So, I changed my rating to an OK.
  288. I have read several of these reviews and find that I am having the same problem: the bulbs die out and cannot be replaced unless I return the product to the manufacturer. The brochure that came w/ this stated these \\"should never need replacing.\\" However, it states that if this \\"malfunction\\" should occur, I should return it and they will service it. Because it is more than 1 y old, I have no idea what the cost of this will/would be. Based on reports in reviews, I have to wonder if this is worth the time/trouble/cost of shipping. Actually, I feel fortunate that these lasted more than 1 y based on many of these reviews! What a shame!! This product has many design features that I really like, but next time I will go w/ a product that has lighting that can be replaced---really there are no light bulbs (even fluorescent) that last all that long!

  308. Just received and set up this mirror on my vanity/desk. I wish I had paid closer attention to the size dimensions, because it is pretty small for what I wanted it for. However, that is my fault. If you have limited space, 9\\" x 12\\" (fully extended) may work for you. There are several color settings for the lighting such as day, evening, home and office. The day is bright white, the office turns me green, the evening is just kind of dim, and the home gives me a rosy glow. If lighting in restaurants were like the home setting, I would be a happy person. I'll never use the office setting and probably not the evening. I think day has the most honest light, so I will probably use that the most.<br /><br />The mirror is made of plastic which gives it a cheap look and feel, but it will do the job. The competitor mirrors were all made of plastic, too, so I don't really hold that against it. I liked it for the folding sides, so that it can be angled to see different areas. This is a nice feature and the sides stay in place where I set them. It was not expensive, so it is a decent value for the price.<br /><br />There are warnings on the mirror and paperwork enclosed that flickering may occur. This did happen a lot after I first set it up. There is a gas in the lamps that moves about and it was probably stirred up from shipping. I turned it on and off a few times, like the warning said to. It helped some, but the flickering didn't go away right away. I tapped lightly on the light and it eventually settled into a steady light. Honestly I think most of this flickering was due to shipping and it just needed to settle. It says flickering can happen from uneven electrical current from your outlet, too. If that happens, it says to turn it on and off until it goes away. I am not there yet.
  309.   366. Hate to write this but I got this mirror on November 5, 2012 (2nd one: see explan. later). It is now July 25 of 2013 as I write this. This mirror was originally great, I didn't have to hold the button down long at all and it was nice and bright. Now, almost 9 months later, the right bulb barely even has a glow in it. It wasn't a slow burnout, just all of a sudden one day. I am very handy so I decided to take it apart and see if I could just order a replacement bulb somewhere. The mirror warns on the back, \\"do not open - no user serviceable parts inside\\". I figure I can get it back together, and save the time, effort and money of trying to return it and ship it back...AGAIN.... ( yes, the first day I received the first one, it wasn't working correctly, so I sent that one back immediately since I still had the box). This is actually my number TWO of these.<br /><br />The back-side screws are hidden under the flat white plastic discs inserted on the back to hide them - they look like a permanent part but they pry out fairly easily. I don't know if I can get the slider that changes the lighting effects colors to hook back up again ( I always use it on the brightest setting so not impt to me to try very long), but as long as there are 2 bulbs in it (even if one doesn't work, at least one may work as mine is now - if 2 bulbs aren't in it, it wont work at all).<br /><br />I have taken pics and measurements of the approximately 8-7/8\\" 2-pin single linear tube fluorescent bulb that says \\"CH Lighting F6T5/CW\\" to start looking for replacement bulbs before putting it back in so I can at least use 1 side's light. It is a tricky-take-apart as they warn. The bulbs' pins fit into metal \\"pin clasps\\" and I got them back in with some very delicate & patient prying. If I find replacements, I will see if Amazon will let me post more info here. If not, I'm looking at specialty lighting stores in my area. I'm pretty sure I'd rather just buy a different kind of mirror if I can't find the bulbs, I bet they wont take it back, esp after this long and that I have messed with it.<br /><br />Anyway, it is a shame that this had to happen, I was really liking this mirror. My last Clairol mirror last at least 12-15 years or more, shame things are built to break sooner now.<br /><br />#UPDATE: I emailed the pictures of the bulb and description/measurements and 2 specialty lighting stores have the bulbs in stock for under $6.00 each, and within 15 miles of me. I hope this helps someone else. So many poor people have bitten the bullet and believed the lucky peoples' positive reviews. I thought I was one of them. Now I just feel lucky I can fix it myself!ulbs, I bet they wont take it back, esp after this long and that I have messed with it.<br /><br />Anyway, it is a shame that this had to happen, I was really liking this mirror. My last Clairol mirror last at least 12-15 years or more, shame things are built to break sooner now.<br /><br />#UPDATE: I emailed the pictures of the bulb and description/measurements and 2 specialty lighting stores have the bulbs in stock for under $6.00 each, and within 15 miles of me. I hope this helps someone else. So many poor people have bitten the bullet and believed the lucky peoples' positive reviews. I thought I was one of them. Now I just feel lucky I can fix it myself!

  373. Steven S. Showers, I cannot thank you enough! I had all the same problems as everyone else (flickering for a while, then both bulbs stopped working) and I was firmly on the list of product detractors. But I followed your instructions from March 27 and now it works as good as new! For some reason the act of taking it apart made it work again. Strange but true. Thanks so much for your thoughtful review!! As a convenience, I've copied Steven's instructions into this review, below.<br />_____________________________________________<br /><br />How do you take the Jerdon Model JGL9W apart?<br /><br />DO NOT TRY TO PRY IT APART! That will NEVER work. I tried that. That is some tough plastic. I found out that the back is not made to simply pop off. And no amount of prying will get it off. The unit is held together by four (4) rather substantial screws.<br /><br />Where are the screws? On the back of the unit you will see four (4) round slightly recessed areas. The recessed plastic inside of these four circles hides the screw heads. If you take a medium size phillips screw driver and press it into the center of that circle you should penetrate through the 1/16 inch or so of the covering plastic, and find the screw head right underneath.<br /><br />(I used the word \\"if\\" and \\"should\\" because I removed the plastic with a 5/16 inch forstner bit on my drill press, not knowing what was under there. I thought it was a support post, internally glued, and I was going to separate it from the back by removing the plastic material around it. But, to my surprise, the drill bit hit metal quickly, and in that way I found the screw head.)<br /><br />Note: Before you seperate the front and the back of the unit, use the flat end of a screw driver to pop out the slider knob.<br /><br />With that caveat, when you get those four screws out, the unit comes apart easily.<br /><br />Why did I take it apart? This unit worked fine for one year, and 11 months, wherein, it came to pass, that both of the lights stopped working. Even if you held the switch down for a minute the lights would not light.<br /><br />Now, because both lights would not light, I figured it was probably not an issue with the lights themselves. I thought I might find something wrong with the switch. When I had the unit apart, and I plugged it in, I operated the switch, and it had a different feel to it, it clicked on, and it clicked off. Before I took the unit apart, the switch had no such mechanical feedback. I am not sure what I did to invoke that change in behavior. Nevertheless, I was rewarded for my efforts, as is often the case in situations like this, where you make the effort, but you are not sure exactly what you did to make it work, but by golly, both the lights come on now!<br /><br />And so, if I had not broken one of the small brackets that holds one end of one of the lense movement assemblies during my effort to pry the unit apart with a big screwdriver, I could simply put it back together and give it back to my mom, as the lights appears to work fine now. But because of this broken bracket issue I need to figure out how to glue it back on before I can put it back together. I don't see a major problem there. (Update: that was no problem. I made a new bracket, glued it on, and the unit is reassembled and functioning properly).<br /><br />While looking inside this unit, I must report to you, that it is well made, and quite substantial. I think people who buy this unit are getting a good deal. All electrical connections are made with solid crimp connections, and everything is well insulated. The ballast transformer looks to be so substantial that one might expect it to last for a century or more. And the lense movement assemblies are quite cleverly and substantially designed too.<br /><br />For those of you who want to know how to change the fluorescent light bulbs in this unit, i.e. if they ever did fail, well then, you would take the unit apart as described above. Beyond that,the rest is speculation on my part derived from looking at the issue from the inside. As noted I did not need to replace the bulbs in this unit.<br /><br />Inside the case, on a label close to the bulbs, it tells you what kind of bulb you need. However, the bulbs do not have sockets. They are hard wired in there with crimp connectors. To remove the old bulb or bulbs, you would have to clip the wires close to the bulb pins, remove the old bulbs, and put in the new ones, and then crimp the wires back onto the pins of the new bulb. I suppose you could solder the wires on, using some shrink wrap insulation to make sure that there is no bare metal showing after you are done.<br /><br />For a person to accomplish this successfully, you would need to have some electrical knowledge before hand. Not a lot, but some. Like don't work on the unit while it's plugged in. And how to crimp, or solder, and how to insulate the bulb pin connections. And how to keep track of where the wires go. You could take a digital photo first, before you disconnect anything.<br /><br />Moreover, the replacement of the light bulbs would be further complicated by the fact that these light bulbs are mounted inside of the lens movement mechanisms. It appears that the main mounting bracket (one per side) for the lens movement mechanism must be unscrewed and moved at least partially out of the way before you can get your hands on the phenolic strips which serve as the mounting structure for the bulbs, and through which the pins extend. I poked around in there and tried to see how these might come out. It is not clear. It Looks like somewhat of a mechanical puzzle. And when it comes to the lens movement mechanism, we are speaking about a string driven spring loaded apparatus, and it will take some mechanical aptitude to get it put back together and properly realigned, that is tracking from side to side.<br /><br />(To adjust tracking, you need to relieve the string tension on one side, and spin the lens into the proper position. I needed to do this before I put this unit back together.)<br /><br />Replacing the light bulbs in this unit is not impossible. But it would NOT be considered easy. Apart from the time it would take to find the right replacement bulbs, and have them at hand ready to install, I think you would be talking about a couple of hours of shop time, factoring in the time you will need to explore and fathom just how to get the old bulbs out of there.<br /><br />A factory technician who has done this a hundred times, who has the bulbs, the tools, and the experience, might be able to complete the job in about fifteen minutes. A person who sees the inside of this unit for the first time will take longer.<br /><br />If you are electrically and mechanically inclined, and have the time to spare, it might be an enjoyable project, which would pay some dividends, I think, in terms of making the end-user very happy. Giving new life to an old friend will certainly give her something to smile about.de. As noted I did not need to replace the bulbs in this unit. Inside the case, on a label close to the bulbs, it tells you what kind of bulb you need. However, the bulbs do not have sockets. They are hard wired in there with crimp connectors. To remove the old bulb or bulbs, you would have to clip the wires close to the bulb pins, remove the old bulbs, and put in the new ones, and then crimp the wires back onto the pins of the new bulb. I suppose you could solder the wires on, using some shrink wrap insulation to make sure that there is no bare metal showing after you are done. For a person to accomplish this successfully, you would need to have some electrical knowledge before hand. Not a lot, but some. Like don't work on the unit while it's plugged in. And how to crimp, or solder, and how to insulate the bulb pin connections. And how to keep track of where the wires go. You could take a digital photo first, before you disconnect anything. Moreover, the replacement of the light bulbs would be further complicated by the fact that these light bulbs are mounted inside of the lens movement mechanisms. It appears that the main mounting bracket (one per side) for the lens movement mechanism must be unscrewed and moved at least partially out of the way before you can get your hands on the phenolic strips which serve as the mounting structure for the bulbs, and through which the pins extend. I poked around in there and tried to see how these might come out. It is not clear. It Looks like somewhat of a mechanical puzzle. And when it comes to the lens movement mechanism, we are speaking about a string driven spring loaded apparatus, and it will take some mechanical aptitude to get it put back together and properly realigned, that is tracking from side to side. (To adjust tracking, you need to relieve the string tension on one side, and spin the lens into the proper position. I needed to do this before I put this unit back together.) Replacing the light bulbs in this unit is not impossible. But it would NOT be considered easy. Apart from the time it would take to find the right replacement bulbs, and have them at hand ready to install, I think you would be talking about a couple of hours of shop time, factoring in the time you will need to explore and fathom just how to get the old bulbs out of there. A factory technician who has done this a hundred times, who has the bulbs, the tools, and the experience, might be able to complete the job in about fifteen minutes. A person who sees the inside of this unit for the first time will take longer. If you are electrically and mechanically inclined, and have the time to spare, it might be an enjoyable project, which would pay some dividends, I think, in terms of making the end-user very happy. Giving new life to an old friend will certainly give her something to smile about.

  380. I bought this based on its reviews, but it is just okay. The shipping was quick, and it was packed well. The biggest problem is that the light is not bright, even on daylight setting. The light is adjusted by colored filters moving across the bulbs, but they are not lined up well. So, when daylight is selected, I can see green bars along the edges of light. Additionally, part of the stand on the back is made of flimsy plastic and represents a very weak, unstable base that could easily break. Finally, a small thing, but the side doors only close when the unmagnified mirror-side is facing out. It's an annoying thing to have to keep flipping the mirror over in order to close the doors. Overall, I would not recommend this mirror if you are the least bit visioned-challenged. It simply is not bright enough.

The packaging contained a polite little notice that fluctuating currents in home electricity can cause flickering, but somehow every other light in my house manages just fine.<br /><br />The design of this mirror is great, so if you don't care about having lights it's wonderful. I just wish Jerdon would figure out their lighting because their designs are great -- and somehow every other electrical appliance, large or small, manages to handle the &#34;fluctuating currents.&#34;

  419. Jerdon JGL9W Tri-Fold Lighted Mirror - Fluorescent bulb on left side is dull while the bulb on right side is bright. Purchased this item in February and I am very dissatisfied with this product.
  420. I bought this lighted mirror in Dec 2010 so we got about 18mos out of the lamps. I found the review by Kathy (pasted below) really helpful in replacing the lamps. She provided info which is hard to find on the web. However, it wasn't quite as easy as she suggests so here's a few more tips. Use a pointed tool to pick the screw covers out of their seats. The plastic case will open after the screws are removed BUT the halves will still be held together by the sliding switch for the color filter which is spring loaded. Pry the plastic slider/switch off to separate the case halves. At this point wires will still attach the halves but the halves can be folded flat on a work surface. The wires to each end of the lamp slide off with help of needle-nose pliers. The insulator/board bulb-mount can be removed by pushing the plastic tab away near the top. I paid about $9/lamp at Home Depot so the $19 total repair cost versus new is questionable. I think it's designed to be a throw-away item given the repair effort. The design engineer should be ashamed of his work.<br />************************************************************************************<br />5.0 out of 5 stars I replaced the tubes!, March 22, 2012<br />By Kathy (Maple Valley, WA) - See all my reviews<br />This review is from: Jerdon Classic JGL9W Lighted Tri-fold Mirror, 5x Magnification (Health and Beauty)<br />I really like this tri-fold mirror, and was very unhappy when, after a little more than 1 year, the lights burned out. And even unhappier when I learned that I would have to send this to the manufacturer for them to replace the lights. Really? No, I don't believe I will do that. I was hopeful that by holding the on button down for 10 seconds as suggested by another reviewer would work, but the light is definitely burned out. I was not pleased with the selection of lighted make-up mirrors at Bed, Bath, and Beyond, which is where I originally purchased this mirror. So, I figured this was useless without the lights anyway, I may as well open it up to see if I could replace the lights. On the back of the mirror case, there are 4 indentations that cover the screws, and once you pop them out, the screw heads are visible. Unscrew with a philip's head driver, but be careful when you take the back off to prevent damaging the light filter. I never used the variable lighting, only the \\"day\\" setting, so I just removed the rotating lenses to access the tube. The tubes are easily removed by pulling the copper connections off. The florescent tube replacement is F6T5/CW (CW is for cool white, brighter than soft white). I paid $6.19 for each tube. Plug in the tubes, close the unit, and screw it together, and voila! You have a great make-up mirror.without the lights anyway, I may as well open it up to see if I could replace the lights. On the back of the mirror case, there are 4 indentations that cover the screws, and once you pop them out, the screw heads are visible. Unscrew with a philip's head driver, but be careful when you take the back off to prevent damaging the light filter. I never used the variable lighting, only the \\"day\\" setting, so I just removed the rotating lenses to access the tube. The tubes are easily removed by pulling the copper connections off. The florescent tube replacement is F6T5/CW (CW is for cool white, brighter than soft white). I paid $6.19 for each tube. Plug in the tubes, close the unit, and screw it together, and voila! You have a great make-up mirror.

The 5X magnification is clear and really great for doing my eyebrows. As far as the side mirrors, I haven't really used those yet (my other did not have them) and that's not to say that in time I won't. I'm just not used to them. My only concern is that I don't have a problem with the lights a month from now, so I'm keeping my fingers crossed. I absolutely love everything about this mirror and I would buy it again and I think that it's worth giving it a try!

  436. O.k. this is my second update. After I wrote the last update I contacted the company and they were great. They sent me a new mirror in about 1 day (don't know how that happened but I got it the next day (but they are only in the next state)). Anyway, the new mirror works fine and I'm very pleased with it. So I do recommend this mirror after all.<br /><br />I'm just adding an update to my prior review. About two weeks ago, the light started flickering when I turned the mirror on - eventualy the light stops flickering, but even so, it's not as bright as it was. The right bulb looks about ready to blow out - the top 1/5th is not lit. I tried to return it, but the 'return window' is over and I couldn't find a number to call to complain.<br /><br />I just wanted to warn would-be buyers. I'll stick with stores like Costco next time that have a better return policy.<br /><br />This was my prior review.<br />I purchased this mirror about 1 month ago and have used it daily since. I am very happy with this purchase. It's not quite as large as it looks in the pics, but it's still a very nice size.<br /><br />I've had lighted make-up mirrors for a very long time. I would rate this the best for several reasons.<br /><br />1. I keep it propped open on a dressing table. I think it is very sturdy. As I recall, the piece that props the mirror up is the most flimsy (in other models) and one of the first things to go. This feels solid and there are two pieces used to prop it up.<br /><br />2. The lighting is very good. You have the ability to choose Day, Home, etc., but I generally only ever use Day.<br /><br />3. I especially like the fact that it has two side mirrors so you get to see the parts of you that you never see (and maybe never want to see:)). I've had compliments lately on how I look and I think it's because I apply better make-up.<br /><br />4. The reverse side of the mirror has 5X magnification, and it likewise is a very good mirror - not distorting as I sometimes find magnification mirrors to be.<br /><br />I read some of the other reviews before purchasing but I don't find some of them to be true. The light turns on with a switch very easily; you don't have to press and hold. I've seen that in other models but not this one. Perhaps the manufacturer improved the product since the first reviews were written.<br /><br />All in all, I'm very satisfied with this purchase and I would recommend it to anyone. I believe it is a quality product and I think it will last - it's sturdy, solid and seems to be made of good materials (not flimsy).of the other reviews before purchasing but I don't find some of them to be true. The light turns on with a switch very easily; you don't have to press and hold. I've seen that in other models but not this one. Perhaps the manufacturer improved the product since the first reviews were written. All in all, I'm very satisfied with this purchase and I would recommend it to anyone. I believe it is a quality product and I think it will last - it's sturdy, solid and seems to be made of good materials (not flimsy).
  437. After reading a ton of reviews on different mirrors, I decided to go with this one. I'm glad I did! It's definitely brighter than my other mirror I got from Revlon. I can use it with very little lighting in the room. The only thing I don't like is the different color selections for the lighting - I haven't really found it useful. Other than that, it's a good mirror.
  438. This is the 2nd one i have purchased...using it almost everyday. the mirrors are very clear, i am very satisfied with it, also the extra outlet come in handy.
  439. I think this mirror is great for it's magnification qualities, but it does fall short in the brightness of the light. I thought I could use the light without having my bright bathroom lights on but that is not the case. If you are looking for a mirror with a bright light this is not the one for you.
  440. I'm not one to give negative reviews, but this mirror is awful. Although it has an adjustment to slant, the adjustment is too much between each (so either straight up or way back). The folding side mirrors do not open far enough and the lighting is poor.
  441. THIS IS MY 3RD ONE OVER THE YEARS...IT IS SO EASY TO USE...LOVE THE MAGNIFIED SIDE FOR CLOSE UP EYE MAKE UP APPLICATIONS...THE SIDE MIRRORS WORK GREAT WHEN BLOWING OUT MY HAIR...

  462. My initial impression was, \\"Wow, this is heavy\\"... as I wasn't expecting such a heavy box. I looked at it briefly before wrapping it up for Christmas and initially noticed irregular seam gaps between the front and back case pieces. I figured, oh well... it's only $35 or so.<br /><br />Fast forward to mid-January and my wife really likes it. She was previously just using an oval mirror with a table lamp behind it. I purchased this for her because it seemed like the lighting and mirror setup she had before was inefficient. The light output of this unit is very bright and the ability to tune the color temperature pretty helpful. I've seen other units (Years ago, my stepmother had a very advanced one) that actually turned on different color-corrected bulbs. She had no issues with turning the unit on after I showed her she needed to briefly hold down the ON button to get the ballast to charge. (Thanks to other reviews posted here)<br /><br />In short: The unit is WELL WORTH the price and despite looking like it's of sub-standard quality, it seems great to us.
  463. This Jerdon lighted makeup mirror works very well. As was mentioned in previous reviews, it is necessary to hold the ON button down for a slow count of 8, then release, for the lights to come on. Unlike the instructions printed on the product, the lights on mine do not flicker before coming on. This mirror replaces a similar product by Windmere that I had used for 15 years. The Windmere mirror did not have the side folding mirrors, which I could do without. I wish Jerdon also made this product without the side mirrors. Also, I need to hang the mirror on the wall, so had to tape the metal stand in an upward position and use it to hook on a picture hanger.
  464. This is a lighted make-up mirror that should be taken off the market. A metal bar behind it, stops it from moving to the left. The phone number of the manufacturer, Jerdon, in the brocure, is incorrect. I reached a number of a citizen who says he in inundated with calls of people trying to reach Jerdon, complaining about the very same thing. I e-mailed them, gave them all the information they needed to research and they replied they needed additional information to research it. I finally returned the product.

  485. This Jerdon makeup mirror is just as bright as Clairol's True-To-Light makeup mirror which was discontinued years ago. It's sturdy and magnification is not distorted. The popular oval mirrors out today don't compare in brightness or value for the price. Recommending this to anyone who was a fan of the Clairol mirror. The power button works by pressing and holding down for just a few seconds until the bulbs start to glow; which is typical of fluorescent type of bulbs, and totally normal (worked the same way on the discontinued Clairol True-To-Light).
  486. This is a great mirror for the price. It is hard to find the fold out type mirrors anymore and I love this one.

  496. My last lighted mirror had a switch that required holding the button down in order to start, but this model does not. I know some of the reviews are about holding the switch in the \\"on position\\" but they have changed it to just an \\"on and off\\" switch, at least on the mirror that I received.<br /><br />The only problem that I have had with this mirror is that the lights flicker and dance like crazy when you first turn them on. I was about to return it but after leaving the lights on for about 30 minutes they settled down and worked properly. After the first time you use the mirror the lights only flicker slightly for the first few minutes then smooth out and all is well.<br /><br />Another thing that is different from my last one is that the mirror flips from top to bottom instead of side to side when you switch to the magnified side. I don't like that because I always tilted the mirror slightly to one side to get more light on the eyebrow that I was working on. Plus you must always flip the mirror to the unmagnified side in order to shut the side mirrors when you are finished.<br /><br />The lights are bright and the mirror magnification is great. I would buy it again even with these minor annoyances.
  497. I got this mirror after reading all the reviews, good and bad, thinking I could always return it if I didn't like it. After I took it out of the packaging, I set it up on my vanity and turned it on. There was no problem whatsoever with the lights, and the mirror's size and versatility is just right for my needs.<br />The lights are not very powerful, so don't expect too much unless you have your face close to the mirror.

  499. Call Jerdon, they will send reasonably priced replacement bulbs. Note: you have to pop out the four small covers over holes on the back to get to the screws to take it apart.

  507. I used to have a Clairol mirror that I loved, but after years of use, it finally stopped working. Since it is no longer made, I decided to try the Jerdon mirror. I love this mirror. It is very bright, and I have no trouble getting the lights to come on. Just hold the button for a second--no problem. Anyone who is used to the old Clairol mirrors will love this one even more. I am going to buy my daughters each one for Chrismas. This is the brightest make-up mirror I have found.
  508. First of all I love to read the reviews and look at the pictures. It helps make online shopping so much easier to know what you are getting.<br />This morning my husband and I had a discussion about mirrors. I just turned 55, just got my first pair of real, full-time, long overdue, eyeglasses to replace those reading glasses I have lived in denial with for so long. For a little makeover I got a new hairstyle and, with my new hair and glasses look, I now want to spruce myself up and start wearing makeup more often again too. I discovered though, that you couldn't wear the glasses and apply eye makeup. So I was back to where I was before, not caring about putting on makeup because I simply can't see to apply it. I mentioned, to hubby, I now needed a magnifying mirror.<br />This got started when my husband was looking for a hand-held mirror (for another, non-grooming reason) this morning. At that time I also remembered that back in the late 60's and early 70's, my mom had given me a, variable lighted, standup, swiveling, magnifying, makeup mirror, similar to this style. I think it was a GE brand. I loved it. They were a popular item back then. Today it seems they are hard to find, with only a few models made anymore. I had lost track of that mirror and hadn't thought about needing another makeup mirror until now, 40 years later!<br />The real clincher was that hubby also said he'd always thought it would be great to have a mirror for shaving. (I'm not sure whether he meant tilting or magnifying or both? Yes, of course, we have a regular mirror on the wall we have always used!)<br />I hunted this mirror down on Amazon and the price was right with free shipping. I looked at the Conair model (Conair also has one without the side mirrors). A reviewer mentioned a Jilbere brand. I looked at those too. The Jilbere's were more expensive and the Conair could be had for about $9 less than this Jerdon one. But reviewers convinced me that the Jerdon was better lit. I'm not sure hubby ever considered or knew about mirrors being lit at all, but when he sees it, I know he's going to be a stickler about the lights being bright enough for him. I also know, at my age, how I'd like nice bright lights too. This made the little bit of extra money for better lighting well worth it.<br />I also read a review of the Conair (somewhere, maybe not even Amazon) that complained that the center mirror swivel should be horizontal to tilt without having to adjust the mirror stand, and not vertical. I suppose you can look at it both ways though. The Conair is adjustable horizontally on the mirror stand AND swivels vertically. Maybe the dual action, even if a little more inconvenient, is a plus for you. I opted though, through reading the Jerdon reviews, and the picture showing the horizontal tilt (very helpful), that this made more sense. The Jilbere appears to swivel vertically. (My old GE swiveled vertically, as I remember, and I vaguely recall thinking it wasn't my favorite feature to have to adjust the stand for the horizontal tilt.) I figured the vertical angle views could be adjusted enough for my needs on the side panels. Although the side panels are not magnified (side panels are not magnified on any models at all) this still seemed like the one for me.<br />Pictures of it in different views, especially the closed up view, also revealed that it was styled with clean lines that hubby would like and wouldn't seem like too much of a feminine appliance.<br />I have to laugh though. Hubby indicated a round standing mirror with his hands when talking about it. Oh my, I looked at the hundreds of those babies that are available now. My personal opinion of them is that even the nicest ones look like a chintzy little utility tool item (albeit handy) that was made in China and you got from Fingerhut. The mirror floating in space (but necessarily supported by some apparatus) style just turns me off. There are a few modern looking rectangle, freestanding and wall mounted jobs but they are always more expensive than they I'd care to pay and, in my minds eye, don't look a whole lot different than the little round ones. No matter how they dress it up they just look like a time worn, antiquated (albeit handy!) design. It's sort of like a toaster. There's not much you can do with a toaster that makes it so significantly modernized and updated that it doesn't still look much like any toaster that was made 50 years ago.<br />In reality even the cheapest unlit round ones are ridiculously priced for such small little viewing areas. Forget the designer lit ones with fancy frame and base finishes. They run in the hundreds of dollars! Unbelievable! I also read that the lights are often specialized and irreplaceable. They are often battery operated, no thanks. Features like dimming, color change, or an outlet on the base, wall mounting brackets ect... make the itty-bitty things incredibly pricey. Give me a makeup mirror that looks like an official appliance and doesn't cost an arm and a leg, instead of a cheap looking tool that cost more than my microwave oven! Maybe hubby didn't know they had these big mirrors. I did because I remember my one from the good old days. He's going to love it!<br />Oh, and many thanks to the reviewer that explained about holding the light switch a few seconds. It doesn't bother me to do that and, if I remember correctly, I think I had to hold the switch on my old GE mirror too. One of the first upfront reviews I looked at was the one about the bulbs burning out but the other reviewer, favorably clearing up the mystery, eased my mind. Great piece of advice, instead of thinking the bulbs don't work. When I got the thing I did spot the note right above the button, explaining the holding of the switch also. Some people never read labels though.<br />My next challenge is that those stupid little round mirrors would have fit much better on my tiny little bathroom vanity countertop a whole lot better than this rig, but I'll make it work somehow. After all you can close it up and store it, and those little round ones are pretty much destined to sit on the vanity top all the time.ays more expensive than they I'd care to pay and, in my minds eye, don't look a whole lot different than the little round ones. No matter how they dress it up they just look like a time worn, antiquated (albeit handy!) design. It's sort of like a toaster. There's not much you can do with a toaster that makes it so significantly modernized and updated that it doesn't still look much like any toaster that was made 50 years ago. In reality even the cheapest unlit round ones are ridiculously priced for such small little viewing areas. Forget the designer lit ones with fancy frame and base finishes. They run in the hundreds of dollars! Unbelievable! I also read that the lights are often specialized and irreplaceable. They are often battery operated, no thanks. Features like dimming, color change, or an outlet on the base, wall mounting brackets ect... make the itty-bitty things incredibly pricey. Give me a makeup mirror that looks like an official appliance and doesn't cost an arm and a leg, instead of a cheap looking tool that cost more than my microwave oven! Maybe hubby didn't know they had these big mirrors. I did because I remember my one from the good old days. He's going to love it! Oh, and many thanks to the reviewer that explained about holding the light switch a few seconds. It doesn't bother me to do that and, if I remember correctly, I think I had to hold the switch on my old GE mirror too. One of the first upfront reviews I looked at was the one about the bulbs burning out but the other reviewer, favorably clearing up the mystery, eased my mind. Great piece of advice, instead of thinking the bulbs don't work. When I got the thing I did spot the note right above the button, explaining the holding of the switch also. Some people never read labels though. My next challenge is that those stupid little round mirrors would have fit much better on my tiny little bathroom vanity countertop a whole lot better than this rig, but I'll make it work somehow. After all you can close it up and store it, and those little round ones are pretty much destined to sit on the vanity top all the time.

  510. I purchased this mirror several months ago and use it every day. I am very pleased with it. The lights are bright enough to be able to see well in a pitch-dark room, the settings are perfect for getting rid of pesky shadows, and the magnification is just right to see every little detail. I have not had any issue with the bulbs - they are still as bright and functional as they day I got the mirror (yes, you do have to hold down the 'on' switch for a few seconds to pre-charge the bulbs). I would definitely recommend this product to anyone seeking a lighted makeup mirror, either for a dark room or otherwise.
  511. What a bright change from the dimly lit lighted mirror I had been using! Too bad the local stores don't carry this, but hurrah for Amazon, where one can find ANYTHING, and with free shipping to boot!
  512. The lights will not even come on anymore. Neither lights are working after having it 1 (one) month! I am VERY dissatisfied.

  521. We bought this mirror and within a few months it failed. I managed to get it apart, after figuring out the screw heads were covered plastic caps to hide them. I messed around with the switch and the bulb connections. It appears that the power switch is intermittent, if you switch in on and off several times it finally comes on. The solution was to tape the switch on and use the plug as the switch. For the price they could make this so it lasts longer than a few months. Buy the Vidal Sassoon version if you can find it!!!

  532. So I read all the reviews, good and bad. My opinion of it is that its seriously an awesome mirror, and especially for the price. The mirror is two sides, one side is 5x magnified, good for tweezing my eyebrows and any small blemishes not easily seen, the other side is regular mirror and the side panels that open outwards have regular mirros. The different light setting are pretty cool, some of them are too greenish or blue, but the evening and the daylight lights are very nice. I like using the evening light for most of my stuff, even when doing my hair, it has a warmer more ambient glow, the daylight light is little brighter but still nice for accurate makeup application. The plug thats in the front for using like your blow dryer or flatiron come in handy, its very convenient and cool to have it there. The mirror has an adjustable backing, to how you want to angle it. Overall this is a verrrrry nice product, I recommend it. I've had it for 3 weeks now and no problems. :)
  533. This mirror puts out a good amount of light and folds for easy storage. The only way it could be better would be if it had a retractable cord.
  534. I like the side mirrors which is a feature my old mirror did not have. The mirror is aesthetically appealing and looks good with my other decor. The downsides to this mirror is that I find the magnification fuzzy and blurry. It is 5x so perhaps 4x or 4.5 x would have been better (I'm comparing it to an old mirror which brand I do not know). But the most frustrating part is the stand. The mirror has a flimsy bar with ridges and a silver frame is supposed to fit into a ridge to balance the mirror while it is standing. The bar is too flimsy and does not seem sturdy enough to hold the weight and size of he mirror. Thus it keeps popping out and falling flat. I'm afraid the mirror may crack with the incessant fallings over. I still have my old mirror but one of the bulbs is burnt out and I can't find a replacement. :-(

  537. I have been using a mirror such as this one since I got handed-down my grandmother's old Clairol model in my teens. From the 5 or 6 models I have owned (all manner of brands and price ranges) this one is by far the best. It is brighter, and manages to reduces the \\"dark spots\\" that are so common in mirrors like this one.<br /><br />The reviewer previous, who stated that the trick is in holding the \\"on\\" button, was exactly correct. I can see where less-patient souls may claim that the bulbs are burnt out or that the appliance is defective. More than likely, it is an operator error.<br /><br />The mirror is sturdy and the adjustable angles are very helpful for using on various surfaces, such as when traveling. I will definitely look for this brand IF this mirror ever needs to be replaced.
